elements.title: Category-Defining Visual Hierarchy: Problem Layer Dominates Solution Layer
elements.problem: L2's Problem-First Information Hierarchy (ds-ui-0904-007) establishes three content tiers -- Problem, Category, Proof -- but the visual design must enforce the hierarchy so the host's eye physically cannot skip to the guest match without first absorbing the risk question. In L2's HTML sketch, all three tiers use similar font sizes (1.125rem, 1rem, 1rem) and similar padding (1.5rem). The visual weight difference is carried only by left-border color, which is insufficient to enforce the cognitive sequence Play Bigger requires. Kelly's rejection happened because Bryant's pitch was solution-first -- the visual equivalent of the Proof tier being the biggest, boldest element on screen. The Problem tier must be visually inescapable: it must be the first thing the eye hits, it must carry the heaviest visual weight, and it must create a visual pause (white space below) before the Category tier begins. The style guide's purple palette (#31135D) is currently associated with brand/CTA elements. Using it for the Problem tier would misassign the brand's authority to a question rather than a statement. Instead, the Problem tier should use warm amber tones (from --signal-warn territory) to signal 'this is something you need to consider' while the Category tier uses the authoritative purple to signal 'this is the answer.' This color-coded hierarchy ensures the eye reads: concern (amber), then authority (purple), then evidence (neutral gray).
elements.solution: Redesign the three-tier discovery outreach component with a visual weight system that enforces the problem-first sequence through size, color, spacing, and contrast differentials. (1) Problem Tier: headline in Inter, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), color #8B4513 (warm brown -- reads as serious without alarm). Container background: a warm off-white (#FFF8F0) with left border 4px solid #C4841D (amber). Padding: --spacing-2xl (24px) inside, --spacing-3xl (28px) below the tier to create a visual pause. The problem prompt text uses DM Sans, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-medium (500), color --text-dark (#1a1a1a), line-height --line-height-relaxed (1.6). This is the largest body text on the entire component -- it must feel like a direct, personal question. (2) Category Tier: headline in Inter, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-bold (700), color --primary-purple (#31135D). Container background: --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) with left border 4px solid --primary-purple (#31135D). Padding: --spacing-2xl (24px) inside, --spacing-xl (20px) below. The statement text uses DM Sans, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-normal (400), color --text-dark. The purple signals brand authority: 'this is what we do.' (3) Proof Tier: headline in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-semibold (600), color --text-gray (#6b7280). Container background: --bg-light (#f9fafb), no left border accent. Padding: --spacing-lg (16px) inside. Guest details in Inter, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-normal (400). The guarantee line uses --primary-purple (#31135D), --font-weight-semibold (600) -- the only purple text in Tier 3, drawing the eye to the category promise embedded in the proof. (4) Overall component: max-width --container-sm (640px), white background, --shadow-md (0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.08)) on the outer container, --rounded-2xl (16px) corners. The three tiers are separated by generous spacing, not by divider lines -- the visual breathing room signals deliberate pacing.

evidence.quote: Bryant opens with Landon's details -- schedule, flexibility, start date -- before any problem framing. The visual equivalent: the Proof tier is the only thing on screen, with no Problem or Category tier visible.
evidence.insight: When the solution is visually dominant, the host processes the outreach within their existing category ('another tenant-finding pitch') and rejects it. The Problem tier must be visually inescapable to force category-level processing before solution-level evaluation begins.

evidence.quote: The first offer put on the table in a negotiation has a powerful impact on any other offer that comes after. In category dynamics, an early company that solves the problem will win a powerful place in customers' minds.
evidence.insight: The visual anchor must be the problem, not the solution. If the host's eye first hits the guest details (Proof tier), that data becomes the anchor and the entire outreach is evaluated as 'tenant pitch.' If the eye first hits the risk question (Problem tier), the risk becomes the anchor and the subsequent Category/Proof tiers are evaluated as 'protection offering.'

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The host's eye must follow this path: (1) Problem headline (largest, boldest, warm amber container -- first thing visible above fold). (2) Problem prompt question (largest body text -- reads as personal, direct). (3) Visual pause (28px gap -- eye must cross empty space before Category tier). (4) Category headline (purple, authoritative -- second visual anchor). (5) Category statement (medium body text -- the answer). (6) Proof section (visually quietest -- supporting evidence, not the argument). On mobile: strict vertical stack, all three tiers fully visible with scroll. On desktop: single column, centered, max-width 640px -- the component should feel like a letter, not a dashboard.
elements.brand_alignment: The amber-to-purple color progression creates a visual narrative: concern yields to authority. This reinforces Split Lease's brand as the entity that understands your risk (amber) and provides the solution (purple). The purple palette retains its authoritative role per the style guide ('distinctive purple palette that conveys trust and sophistication') while the amber problem tier adds a human urgency layer that the style guide's neutral palette cannot achieve alone. The deliberate visual pacing (generous spacing, single-column layout) aligns with the taste model's principle of 'confident, not flashy -- the product speaks through clarity, not decoration.'

elements.title: Risk-Contrast Card: Side-by-Side Visual Comparison with Asymmetric Weight
elements.problem: L2's Risk-Contrast Comparison Card (ds-ui-0904-008) establishes a two-column grid comparing direct hosting risks against guaranteed-income hosting protections. The L2 sketch uses symmetric visual treatment: both columns have equal font sizes, equal padding, and equal cell heights. This symmetry undermines the category-design intent. Play Bigger teaches that the problem must be visually dominant over the solution -- the host needs to see the risk before they see the protection. In the L2 sketch, both column headers use 0.75rem uppercase text, both cell backgrounds are light tints (warm for risk, cool for protection), and the grid treats both sides as equivalent information. But they are not equivalent: the risk column is the category-defining argument; the protection column is the category-defining promise. The risk column must carry more visual weight because Play Bigger's Anchoring Effect requires the problem to land first. Additionally, the L2 sketch's risk column uses soft, warm colors (#FFF8F0, #FFFBF5) that read as 'gentle advisory' rather than 'real exposure.' For hosts like Kelly who are satisfied with direct hosting, the risk must feel concrete -- not alarming, but undeniable. The visual treatment must make the risk feel tangible without making the host feel attacked.
elements.solution: Redesign the risk-contrast card with asymmetric visual weight that gives the risk column visual dominance while keeping the protection column as the aspirational resolution. (1) Card container: max-width --container-sm (640px), --rounded-xl (12px), --border-color (#e5e7eb) border, --shadow-sm (0 1px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)). Title bar: Inter, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-bold (700), #1a1a1a, padding --spacing-xl (20px) --spacing-2xl (24px), background --bg-light (#f9fafb), bottom border --border-color. The title 'What happens when things go wrong?' uses a question format to activate problem recognition. (2) Risk column (column 2 of 3): header 'Direct hosting' in Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-bold (700), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.06em, color #7C3A00 (dark amber). Background: #FEF0DB (warm amber tint -- stronger than L2's #FFF8F0). Cell backgrounds: #FFF6E8 (slightly stronger warm tint). Cell text: DM Sans, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-medium (500), color #7C3A00. The medium weight and dark amber color give risk cells more visual mass than the protection cells. (3) Protection column (column 3 of 3): header 'Guaranteed-income hosting' in Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-bold (700), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.06em, color --primary-purple (#31135D). Background: --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)). Cell backgrounds: #FAF8FF (very subtle purple tint). Cell text: DM Sans, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-normal (400), color #31135D at 80% opacity. The normal weight (vs. medium for risk) makes protection cells read as resolution, not argument. (4) Dimension labels (column 1): Inter, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-semibold (600), color --text-dark (#1a1a1a). These anchor each row without competing with either column. (5) Visual weight asymmetry: the risk column uses stronger background tints, heavier font weight, and darker tinted text. The protection column uses softer tints, lighter font weight, and semi-transparent text. The host's eye should read the risk first in each row, then find relief in the protection column. This mirrors Play Bigger's sequence: 'make them aware they have a problem, then offer the solution.'

evidence.quote: I'd prefer to just kind of work with individuals directly... I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were.
evidence.insight: Kelly evaluates her hosting approach on one dimension only: personal trust through direct vetting. She has never been shown the other dimensions -- payment risk, damage liability, early departure loss -- in a structured visual format. The risk-contrast card introduces these dimensions visually, surfacing gaps she has not considered.

evidence.quote: One early Life magazine ad showed a woman in pearls lounging on a pillow eating Birds Eye spinach, implying that only commoners put up with canned spinach. Frozen food was not just better than canned food -- it was different from canned food.
evidence.insight: The visual comparison must frame the two approaches as categorically different, not incrementally better/worse. The amber risk column and purple protection column use entirely different color families -- they do not share a palette. This signals that these are not two versions of the same thing but two different categories of hosting.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Within each row: (1) the eye hits the dimension label first (left-aligned, semibold, dark). (2) The eye moves to the risk cell (stronger background tint, heavier font weight -- visually 'louder'). (3) The eye finds resolution in the protection cell (softer tint, lighter weight -- visually 'quieter'). This left-to-right reading creates a micro-narrative in each row: here is the dimension, here is your current exposure, here is the alternative. On mobile: the three-column grid collapses to a stacked format -- dimension label as a header row, then risk and protection as two labeled blocks below it. The risk block should appear first (above the protection block) to maintain the problem-first visual sequence.
elements.brand_alignment: The two distinct color families (amber for risk, purple for protection) reinforce Split Lease's category-defining position: amber says 'this is the world you live in now' and purple says 'this is the world we offer.' The purple column carries the brand's signature palette per the style guide, positioning Split Lease's category as the resolution to a clearly visible problem. The card's restraint (no icons, no illustrations, no animation) aligns with the taste model's 'confident, not flashy' principle -- the data itself makes the argument.

elements.title: Vetting Evidence Trail: Progressive Disclosure with Inspectable Trust Cards
elements.problem: L2's Vetting Evidence Trail (ds-ui-0904-009) introduces an expandable card-based vetting display that addresses Kelly's demand for information depth ('I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information'). The L2 HTML sketch uses a flat visual treatment: all four cards (Employment, Identity, Payment History, Background Check) have identical styling -- same border, same background (#FAFAFA), same padding, same typography. This visual uniformity misses an opportunity to signal information importance through visual weight. Kelly specifically asked about nursing credentials ('their nursing') and personal confidence ('who they were'). Employment and Identity are her primary trust axes. Payment History and Background Check are secondary verification. The visual design must reflect this priority: the cards Kelly cares most about should be visually heavier (larger, more prominent) than supporting verification cards. Additionally, the 'Verified' badges in the L2 sketch use a green background (#E8F5E9) and green text (#2E7D32). The style guide explicitly states that the production system uses purple for success states (--success-green: #4B47CE) -- a critical token drift issue. The verification badges must use the production purple palette, not green, to maintain visual system coherence.
elements.solution: Redesign the vetting evidence trail with a two-tier visual weight system that prioritizes the dimensions Kelly cares about, using the production purple palette for verification badges. (1) Primary verification cards (Employment, Identity): larger, more visually prominent. Card background: white (#ffffff) with --shadow-md (0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.08)) and --rounded-xl (12px) border-radius. Left accent border: 3px solid --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)). Internal padding: --spacing-2xl (24px). Label text: Inter, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-bold (700), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.05em, color --text-dark (#1a1a1a). Summary text: DM Sans, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-normal (400), color --text-description (#374151). The larger font size and shadow elevation make these cards the visual focal point. (2) Secondary verification cards (Payment History, Background Check): smaller, quieter. Card background: --bg-light (#f9fafb), no shadow, --rounded-lg (8px). No left accent border. Internal padding: --spacing-lg (16px). Label text: Inter, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-bold (700), uppercase, color --text-gray (#6b7280). Summary text: DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), color --text-description (#374151). (3) Verification badges: replace L2's green with production purple. Badge background: #EDEAFF (light purple tint). Badge text: #4B47CE (--chat-purple), Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-bold (700), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.05em, border-radius --rounded-pill (20px), padding 3px 10px. This matches the production success color while being visually distinct from interactive elements. (4) Expandable details: use the native HTML <details>/<summary> pattern. Summary trigger text: Inter, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-semibold (600), color --primary-purple (#31135D). On expand: detail grid with dt in --text-gray, dd in --text-dark, --text-sm-md (13px) for both. Background of expanded section: --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6), --rounded-lg (8px), padding --spacing-md (12px). (5) Component header: 'Guest verification' in Inter, --text-lg (18px), --font-weight-bold (700), --text-dark. Subtitle 'Verified before your property was shown' in DM Sans, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-light-gray (#9ca3af). The subtitle reinforces that vetting is proactive, not reactive.

evidence.quote: I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were.
evidence.insight: Kelly names two trust axes: professional credentials ('their nursing') and personal identity ('who they were'). Employment and Identity cards must be visually primary because they answer her specific questions. Payment history and background checks are important but are not what she asked about -- they are supporting evidence, not primary trust signals.

evidence.quote: Once you've committed to a product or service in a new category, you're likely to give positive qualities to an option you've chosen just because you've chosen it.
evidence.insight: Kelly has committed to direct vetting. To overcome Choice Supportive Bias, the visual evidence must be undeniably more thorough than what she can achieve independently. Visual weight signals thoroughness: the primary cards' elevation (shadow), accent border (purple), and larger typography all communicate 'this is comprehensive, verified information you cannot get on your own.'

elements.title: Category Vocabulary Reference Card: Strike-Through to Replacement Visual Pattern
elements.problem: L2's Category-Defining Label System (ds-ui-0904-010) presents a table mapping old intermediation vocabulary to new category-defining vocabulary. The L2 sketch uses a simple table with struck-through old labels and bold purple new labels. While functionally correct, the visual treatment does not create enough cognitive weight to make the vocabulary shift feel important. A table is a reference format -- it organizes information but does not argue for change. Play Bigger's category design requires that the vocabulary shift feel like a paradigm replacement, not a word swap. The visual pattern must make the old vocabulary feel outdated (not just wrong) and the new vocabulary feel inevitable (not just better). Kelly called the call because Bryant used 'matchmaker' -- a word that instantly categorized Split Lease as an intermediary. The vocabulary card must make it viscerally clear that 'matchmaker' is the old category and 'guaranteed-income hosting' is the new one.
elements.solution: Redesign the vocabulary reference as a card-based format where each vocabulary pair occupies its own visual unit, creating a narrative of replacement rather than a static table. (1) Card container: max-width --container-md (900px), no outer border (cards are the visual units), display as a responsive grid (2 columns on desktop, 1 on mobile). (2) Individual vocabulary cards: --rounded-xl (12px), --border-color (#e5e7eb) border, white background, --shadow-sm hover transition (0.2s ease). Internal layout: two rows. Top row (old label): Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), color --text-light-gray (#9ca3af), text-decoration line-through with --border-gray-lighter (#ddd) as the strikethrough color. The faded color and line-through make the old term feel expired -- not wrong, just past. Bottom row (new label): Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-bold (700), color --primary-purple (#31135D). A left accent bar (3px solid --primary-purple) on the bottom row's container visually connects the new vocabulary to the brand. (3) Context label above each card: Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-semibold (600), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.06em, color --text-gray (#6b7280). Examples: 'AGENT ROLE,' 'SERVICE DESCRIPTION,' 'OUTREACH OPENER.' (4) Visual transition between old and new: a thin divider line (1px solid --border-light (#f3f4f6)) between the old and new rows, with the new row having a background tint of --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)). This creates a visual before/after within each card. (5) Section header: 'Category vocabulary' in Inter, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), --text-dark (#1a1a1a). Subtitle: 'Replace intermediation language with outcome language' in DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-gray (#6b7280).

evidence.quote: I work basically as a matchmaker between like these types of guests and hosts.
evidence.insight: This single sentence categorized Split Lease as an intermediary. The vocabulary card must make 'matchmaker' visually feel like an expired term -- faded, struck through, past tense -- while 'hosting protection manager' feels current, bold, and authoritative. The visual treatment of the word itself changes how the reader processes the concept.

evidence.quote: Three times Jawbone came up with cool innovations that created a brand-new product category. But three times, Jawbone failed to develop and dominate the category it created.
evidence.insight: Jawbone failed at category design despite product innovation because its vocabulary never shifted. 'Wireless headset' mapped to the existing category. The vocabulary card is a category-design tool: it systematically replaces every word that maps to the old category, reducing the risk of a Jawbone-style vocabulary failure.

(2) New vocabulary (bold, purple, brand-tinted background -- the answer). (3) Old vocabulary (faded, struck through -- the thing being replaced). The new label should be read first despite being positioned second because its visual weight (bold, purple, larger, tinted background) is dominant. The old label is visually recessive, serving as context for why the new label exists. Across the grid: cards should be read left-to-right, top-to-bottom, each one reinforcing the pattern: old category is over, new category is here.
elements.brand_alignment: The purple new-vocabulary row with its left accent bar creates a direct visual link to Split Lease's brand. Every new term carries the brand's signature color, embedding the category-defining vocabulary into the brand's visual identity. The faded old terms create contrast that makes the purple feel even more authoritative. This aligns with the style guide's philosophy: 'clean, modern interfaces with a distinctive purple palette that conveys trust and sophistication.'

elements.title: Local Social Proof Notification: Geo-Anchored Compact Card with Purple Accent
elements.problem: L2's Local Social Proof Notification (ds-ui-0904-011) is designed for SMS/email delivery to pre-category hosts like Kelly who declined but left the door open. The L2 sketch uses a compact card format that is functionally sound but visually could be confused with a marketing email or promotional notification. Play Bigger's Groupthink Bias research shows that social proof must feel informational, not promotional -- the signal is 'other people near you are doing this' not 'buy this now.' The L2 sketch's visual treatment uses a light purple background (#FAFAFF) and a thin border (#E8E4F0) that resembles a standard platform notification. For a pre-category host who has already rejected the platform, any visual resemblance to marketing triggers deletion before reading. The notification must look like a data update from a trusted local source, not like a promotional message. The geographic anchor ('In Troy, MI') is small and subordinate in the L2 sketch. For Groupthink Bias to activate, the location must be the most visually prominent element -- because the power of the signal is not 'people are using this' but 'people NEAR YOU are using this.' The proximity is what triggers the brain's error signal.
elements.solution: Redesign the social proof notification as a data-forward card where the geographic location is visually dominant and the overall aesthetic reads as 'neighborhood update' rather than 'platform marketing.' (1) Card container: max-width 380px (optimized for mobile preview), white background (#ffffff), --rounded-xl (12px), --shadow-sm (0 1px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)), --border-color (#e5e7eb) border. White background reads as informational (not promotional purple tint). (2) Geographic anchor (top of card, visually dominant): the location text 'Troy, MI' in Inter, --text-md (16px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D). Accompanied by a small map-pin icon (16x16px) in --primary-purple. This is the largest, boldest text on the card -- it must be read first. Below: 'Guaranteed-income hosting update' in Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-semibold (600), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.06em, --text-gray (#6b7280). (3) Social proof signal (middle of card): the count number in Inter, --text-2xl (28px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple. Example: '3'. Followed by 'property owners now use guaranteed-income hosting' in DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-dark (#1a1a1a). The large purple number creates visual gravity -- the eye hits the count before reading the context. (4) Outcome data: '$12,400 in guaranteed income paid this month' in DM Sans, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-gray (#6b7280). Smaller, quieter than the count -- it is supporting evidence, not the headline. (5) Reconnection line: separated by a 1px --border-light (#f3f4f6) divider. 'Bryant is still your hosting protection manager.' in DM Sans, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-light-gray (#9ca3af). The personal name 'Bryant' is the only warm element in this section -- it should not be bolded or colored, just present. The quietness signals 'no pressure.' (6) No CTA button. No 'Learn More.' No 'Sign Up.' The card is pure information. The reconnection line provides a path without demanding action.

evidence.quote: You're calling from Michigan, right? ... I'm right outside, I'm sort of in like Metro Detroit right outside Detroit City... I know your way, Troy.
evidence.insight: Kelly and Bryant share geographic identity. The mutual recognition of 'Troy' created a moment of warmth in an otherwise-rejected call. The notification leverages this by leading with the geographic anchor -- 'Troy, MI' is not just a location filter, it is an identity signal that says 'this is about your neighborhood, not about a platform.'

evidence.quote: Brain studies have shown that when we hold an opinion that differs from others' in a group, our brains produce an error signal, warning us that we are probably wrong.
evidence.insight: The large purple count number ('3') is the visual trigger for the brain's error signal. When Kelly sees that 3 property owners in her area are using guaranteed-income hosting, her brain registers a discrepancy between her opinion ('I work directly') and her neighbors' behavior ('they use the platform'). The number must be visually inescapable for this mechanism to activate.

elements.title: Post-Rejection Category Seed Card: Minimal Imprint for Long-Term Recall
elements.problem: L2's Post-Rejection Category Seed Card (ds-ui-0904-012) is sent within 30 minutes of a declined call to replace the incorrect category label ('matchmaker') with the correct one ('guaranteed-income hosting'). The L2 sketch uses a centered card with generous padding, a warm purple scenario section, and a contact block. The visual design is well-structured but potentially too elaborate for a post-rejection context. Kelly just declined -- she does not want to engage with a complex artifact. The seed card must be visually minimal enough to be processed in 5 seconds (a glance, not a read) but memorable enough that the category label persists in Kelly's mind for months. Research on the Anchoring Effect shows that anchors are set by brief, early exposure -- not by detailed explanation. The card's visual design must prioritize the category name ('Guaranteed-Income Hosting') as a visual anchor that can be set in a single glance. Everything else on the card is supporting context, not primary information. The L2 sketch gives equal visual weight to the category definition, the scenario, and the contact block. The category name must dominate.
elements.solution: Redesign the seed card as a minimal, single-focal-point artifact where the category name is the overwhelming visual anchor. (1) Card container: max-width 360px (smaller than L2's 400px -- compactness signals 'not a marketing piece'). White background, --rounded-2xl (16px), --shadow-md (0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.08)). No border -- the shadow provides containment without the formality of a border. (2) Category name (visual anchor, must be set in 1 second): 'Guaranteed-Income Hosting' in Inter, --text-xl (20px), --font-weight-bold (700), --primary-purple (#31135D), text-align center. This is the only purple text on the card. It should be the first and last thing the host remembers. Below: a 2px, 40px-wide horizontal rule in --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)), centered -- a visual period that signals 'this is the headline, pause here.' (3) Category definition (secondary, processed in 2-3 seconds): two lines of text in DM Sans, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-dark (#1a1a1a), text-align center, line-height --line-height-relaxed (1.6). 'You get paid whether the guest stays or not. Every guest is verified before they see your property.' Short, declarative, no jargon. (4) Scenario block (tertiary, optional reading): a compact block with --bg-light (#f9fafb) background, --rounded-lg (8px), padding --spacing-md (12px). Label: 'IF A TENANT STOPS PAYING' in Inter, --text-xs (11px), --font-weight-bold (700), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.06em, --text-gray (#6b7280). Body: 'You still get paid through the full lease term.' in DM Sans, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-description (#374151). The scenario block is deliberately subdued -- it plants a seed without demanding attention. (5) Contact block (lowest priority): separated by generous white space (--spacing-xl, 20px), not a divider line. 'Bryant' in Inter, --text-base (14px), --font-weight-semibold (600), --text-dark. 'Your hosting protection manager in Troy, MI' in DM Sans, --text-sm (12px), --font-weight-normal (400), --text-light-gray (#9ca3af). Phone number in Inter, --text-sm-md (13px), --font-weight-medium (500), --primary-purple (#31135D) -- the only other purple element, connecting the contact to the brand. (6) No logo, no tagline, no illustrations. The card is pure text and white space. Its restraint is what distinguishes it from marketing.

evidence.quote: Bryant: 'I work basically as a matchmaker between guests and hosts.' Kelly: 'That's a good opportunity that you offer, but I just prefer to work with the person directly.'
evidence.insight: Kelly's memory of this call will be anchored to the word 'matchmaker' -- the category label Bryant used. The seed card's primary job is to replace that anchor. 'Guaranteed-Income Hosting' must be the most visually dominant element because it is the replacement anchor. If Kelly sees this card once and remembers one thing, it must be the category name, not the scenario or the contact info.

evidence.quote: The first offer put on the table in a negotiation has a powerful impact on any other offer that comes after.
evidence.insight: The seed card is a second anchor attempt. The first anchor ('matchmaker') was set during the call. The card must set a competing anchor ('guaranteed-income hosting') that will persist in Kelly's mind. Anchor persistence depends on visual salience and simplicity -- the simpler and bolder the anchor, the longer it lasts. Hence the minimal design: one bold purple headline, everything else quiet.

elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The card has one visual focal point: the purple category name 'Guaranteed-Income Hosting.' Everything else radiates outward from this anchor in decreasing visual weight: (1) Category name (bold, purple, centered -- 1 second). (2) Horizontal rule (visual pause -- 0.5 seconds). (3) Category definition (two lines of dark text -- 2 seconds). (4) Scenario block (gray background, smaller text -- 3 seconds if read). (5) Contact block (lightest text -- noticed, not actively read). The card should be fully scannable in 5 seconds. A host who glances at it for 2 seconds should walk away remembering 'Guaranteed-Income Hosting' in purple. That is the design's success criterion. On mobile: renders as a compact, portrait-oriented card that fits within a single screen without scrolling.
elements.brand_alignment: The extreme restraint of this card is its brand signal. In a world of noisy marketing emails and promotional notifications, a card with one bold purple headline, two lines of text, and a quiet contact block communicates: 'we respect your time and your decision.' This aligns with the taste model's 'confident, not flashy' and 'premium-accessible' principles. The purple category name carries the entire brand weight -- it does not need a logo or gradient to signal Split Lease. The simplicity is the sophistication.
